title: Off Guard: Johnny Case thriving in Vegas ahead of Rizin FF lightweight GP
text:
Johnny Case has moved to Las Vegas, and he’s feeling the benefits as he prepares to take on the best lightweights Rizin has to offer during their lightweight grand prix tournament.

Case takes on Roberto Souza in the quarterfinals of the eight-man tourney at Rizin FF 19 on Oct. 12 and he recently spoke to MMA Junkie about his upcoming challenge.

“It is such an honor to be able to fight in Rizin and fight for the grand prix tournament,” Case said. “I was looking back, someone tagged me on Twitter the original grand prix. It was a 16-man (tournament). To see some of the legendary names that fought on that one, and now I’m part of that history. I’ll be remembered as the Rizin lightweight champion of the world. That’s such an awesome honor.”

Case went 4-2 in the UFC earlier in his career, and also fought once in the PFL, but says there’s nowhere else he’d rather be than with the Japanese promotion at this stage in his career.

“Oh yeah, Rizin is the best promotion to fight for, hands down,” he stated. “They’re super fair, they pay everything up front. It’s not like in America where you get half if you fight and half if you win. Your pay is your pay, you just go and perform, put on a good show and they honor and respect that. It’s been great, and I don’t picture myself fighting anywhere else.”

Since losing his final UFC bout to Anthony Rocco Martin in June 2017, Case has been on a tear and heads into the lightweight grand prix riding a five-fight unbeaten streak, which includes back-to-back stoppage wins in Rizin.

Now he’s looking to run through the tournament and raise championship gold as the promotion’s top 155-pounder. But while his goal is ultimately to win the title, he said he’s taking things one step at a time.

“I try not to put it on a pedestal too much,” he said of the tournament. “It’s always been the same for me, preparation, performance and payday. So that’s all I’m focused on. I’m focused on one opponent and one goal at a time. And if I do that, it’ll play out like it’s supposed to play out.”

Case’s form has coincided with him moving to Las Vegas where he has found new focus and clarity in his career. The move, he says has been a huge catalyst in his improved performances and he can’t wait to continue that trend through the upcoming tournament.

Listing the factors that have sparked his improved form, Case said: “Moving to Las Vegas, meeting my girlfriend Emily Whitmire, my perspective on life. I was kinda living half-foot in the door, half-foot out. Is fighting what I’m really want to be doing? Am I going to be able to pay the bills? Now it’s like everything’s good in my life. I’m happy, I’m focused, I’m passionate, I’ve got the fire lit again, and that’s been the difference, man.”
description: Johnny "Hollywood" Case talks moving to Las Vegas and loving life in Rizin ahead of the Japanese promotion's lightweight grand prix.
